PARAGRAPH.STRING: is the tallest and most prominent mountain in the Olympic Mountains range of Western Washington. Located on the Olympic Peninsula,
is the central feature of Olympic National Park.

is the highest summit of the Olympic Mountains, however, peaks such as Mount Constance, on the eastern margin of the range, are more visible from the Seattle metropolitan area. With notable local relief,
ascends over 2,100 metres (6,900 ft) from the 293 metres (961 ft) elevation confluence of the Hoh River with Hoh Creek in only 8.8 km (5.5 mi).

modest elevation, 2,427 metres (7,963 ft), and relatively low latitude (48°). These glaciers include Blue, Hoh, Humes, Jeffers, Hubert, and White, the longest of which is Hoh at 4.93 kilometres (3.06 mi). The largest is Blue with a volume of 0.57 km³ and area of 5.31 km².
was sighted in 1774 by the Spanish explorer Juan Perez, who named
"El Cerro de la Santa Rosalia". This is said to be the first European to name a geographic feature in present-day Washington state. In 1778, on July 4, the British explorer John Meares gave
